entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony's journal entry from 1878, no specific date mentioned, where she writes a note about a lost book.

entries.fullText:
DOMESTIC POSTAGE.
On all LETTERS throughout the United States, 3 cts. for each half ounce or fraction thereof; if prepaid one full rate the deficient postage is collected on delivery.
DROP or LOCAL LETTERS, 2 cts. per half ounce where there is a free carrier's delivery: other offices, 1 ct.
POSTAL CARDS, 1 ct each.
VALUABLE LETTERS may be registered by the payment of a registration fee of 10 cts. MONEY can be sent with absolute safety by mail, by procuring a Money Order. The fees are: on orders not exceeding $15, 10 cts ; $15 to $30, 15 cts. ; $30 to $40, 20 cts. ; $40 to $50, 25 cts.
PRINTED BOOKS in one package, to one address, 1 ct. for each 2 ounces or fraction thereof, not over 4 lbs.
On TRANSIENT NEWSPAPERS and other printed matter (except Circulars), 1 ct. for 2 ounces or part of 2 ounces, not over 4 lbs.
On Circulars, Seeds, Cuttings, Bulbs, Roots, Scions, Samples of Merchandise (except Liquids and Glass), Minerals, Ores, Flexible Patterns, Photographs, Stereoscopic Views, Paper, Envelopes, and all other articles not from their form or nature calculated to injure the mails, 1 ct. for each ounce, not over 4 lbs.
Any package may have the name and address of the sender, with the word 'From' prefixed on the wrapper, and the number and names of the articles may be attached in brief form.
All transient matter must be fully prepaid by stamps.
On matter not above specified, same rate as Letters.
All matter, except Letters, must be also inclosed that a free inspection is allowed, without cutting strings or wrapper.
entries.summaryText: Details on domestic postage rates and regulations for letters, postal cards, printed matter, and other articles.

entries.fullText:
FOREIGN POSTAGE.
To all parts of EUROPE and BRITISH INDIA, for Letters, 5 cts. per half ounce, prepayment optional; if not prepaid, a fine is collected on delivery. Postal Cards, 1 ct. in addition to stamp impressed. Newspapers, 2 cts. each, if not over 4 ounces, and 2 cts. for each additional 4 ounces or part thereof. For other printed matter and Samples, 2 cts. for each 2 ounces or part of 2 ounces. All matter, except Letters, must be prepaid. Letters and other packages may be registered on payment of a fee of 10 cts. The fees for Money Orders on Great Britain and Ireland and Switzerland are : not over $10, 25 cts. ; $10 to $20, 50 cts. ; $20 to $30, 75 cts. ; $30 to $40, $1.00 ; $40 to $50 $1.25. On Germany, not over $5, 15 cts. ; $5 to $10, 25 cts. ; $10 to $20, 50 cts. ; $20 to $30, 75 cts. ; $30 to $40, $1.00 ; $40 to $50, $1.25.
To the DOMINION OF CANADA, NEW BRUNSWICK, NOVA SCOTIA, &c., Letters, Postal Cards, Printed Matter, Samples, &c., must be prepaid same as U. S. rates, except Samples are 10 cts. for any weight within the limit of 8 ounces, which must not be exceeded. The fees for money Orders on Canada are : not over $10, 20 cts. ; $10 to $20, 40 cts. ; $20 to $30, 60 cts. ; $30 to $40, 80 cts. ; $40 to $50, $1.00.
To NEWFOUNDLAND, per half ounce, 5 cts., prepayment compulsory. Postal Cards 1 ct. extra, each.
entries.summaryText: Details on foreign postage rates and regulations for letters, postal cards, printed matter, and other articles.

entries.fullText:
STAMP DUTIES.
CHECKS, DRAFTS, NOTES, ORDERS, &c., if paid by Bank, Banker, or Trust Company, are subject to a stamp duty of 2 cts. ; all other instruments are exempt.
entries.summaryText: Details on stamp duties for checks, drafts, notes, orders, and other instruments.

people: Rev. and Mrs. B. W. Brigham
entries.fullText:
Lovely day - but no flying
Spring Valley - Minn $30
Pay J. Sargent
Left LaCrosse at 8.38 AM. arrive
at noon - First eveing of the winter
that the roads have been frozen hard - good [good?]?

Good letter from Sister May
mailed [?] 29th - she gets on my
[?] with [Pennie?] & Louise
splendid - Mother smart - but losing
her mental [?] faster than physical.
It is too bad. -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her day in Spring Valley, Minnesota, where she received a good letter from her sister May and expresses concern about her mother's mental health.

people: Rev. and Mrs. B. W. Brigham
entries.fullText:
Went back to LaCrosse,
Wis - in P.M - Rev. and Mrs.
B. W. Brigham - [?] called & subscribed for B.D.
a most delightful winter
day - it is so good to see
the sun - for two months
it has very seldom been
seen - Hear of Wendell Phillips lecturing all around
but no where that I can see or
hear him - how I [?] to -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony returns to LaCrosse, Wisconsin and enjoys a delightful winter day, but expresses disappointment at not being able to see or hear Wendell Phillips' lectures.

entries.cityOrState: Prairie Du Chien - Wis, Lansing - Iowa
entries.fullText:
Prairie Du Chien - Wis
Lansing - Iowa - $30
W. F. Purdy
Sent $50 to Mrs. Sargent - making
$200. to N.W.S.A. -
Splendid audience
- several ladies called
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks in Prairie Du Chien and Lansing, sends money to Mrs. Sargent, and has a splendid audience.

entries.cityOrState: Prairie du Chien - Wis, McGregor Depot
entries.fullText:
Prairie du Chien - Wis -
S.[?] Geo. Schnietzer [sp?] -
Staffer at N. N. Hotel -
Mr. Williams Proprietor
Cousin Gilbert Luther - [Liden?] May Luther's brother came
to the McGregor Depot to see him
a few minutes - his aunt Chloe [B?te] - [?] feeble -
small audience
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks in Prairie du Chien, meets with family, and has a small audience.

entries.fullText:
$25
Charles City - Iowa
Mrs. R. S. Andrews
stopped at Mrs. Molley's
sister of Mrs. Andrews -
Bitter cold night - wind
fearful - small audience
yet larger by 20 or 30 then
Phoebe [Cousins?] was
Mr. Stevens wouldn't allow
his wife to invite me to stay with her.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks in Charles City, stays at Mrs. Molley's, and has a small audience.

entries.fullText:
Dined at Cousin Ruth
Luther's - husband's
name Charles - her father
mother's Cousin, Gilbert [Gilhaus?]
Aunt Chloe Richardson's son -
rode 12 miles on horseback-
suffered cold & terribly rough roads -
Spoke in M.E. Church in eve?
- gave Social Purity - the pastor
said at close he no respect for anybody's
opinion, who doubted the propriety
of his giving his pulpit to Miss A.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony dines with family, speaks at a church, and discusses Social Purity.

entries.fullText:
Nashua - Ia $35
I. A. Rutherford
stopped hotel - Mrs. M. H. Leight
a sister of Mrs.Harris of Ripon, Wis
splendid audience - __ my best -
- easy sailing? speech
entries.summaryText: Speech in Nashua, IA with a splendid audience.

entries.fullText:
Waverly - Iowa $30
F. G. Ball -
Stopped Waverly Hotel
Rev. Horence (sp?) E. Hollock -
pastor of Universalist Church
introduced me - handsome(y?)
her sister H. M. Hollock with her - but doctor in ____?
Splendid audience - and invited back for another lecture -
entries.summaryText: Speech in Waverly, IA with a splendid audience and invited back for another lecture.

entries.fullText:
Greene - Iowa - $30 M. W. Riner
Stopped at C. T. Lamson's -
night - snowy & rainy - & very slushy & cold - Small audience
no roll of petitions
____ (viewed?) for over 4 weeks
entries.summaryText: Speech in Greene, IA with a small audience.

entries.fullText:
Marble Rock, IA
$30
Geo. H. Nichols
Mrs. Polland - called
Large audience
entries.summaryText: Speech in Marble Rock, IA with a large audience.

entries.fullText:
Shell Rock - Ia - $30.
E. E. Savage
Rode to Greene in sleigh in 40 minutes
stopped with Mrs. Nate J. Carter
- got letter from Sister Mary
Poor Dennis slid off again on you! L. M.
too bad, after such good hopes raised for a whole month and then to start the new year so - it is too discouraging - & clear weather, too - on Jan. 1 - put pen to paper & wrote guide a trembling word to all of her children -
Large audience
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her travels to Shell Rock, Iowa, where she received a letter from her sister and had a large audience.

people: Dr. J. Wasson Ed. La Porte City
entries.fullText:
$30?
La Porte City, Ia
A. G. Pierce -
Stopped Hotel - Dr. J. Wasson Ed. La Porte City - Progress -
brother of Charlotte W. Cox of Mendon - Monroe C. ??
Mrs. Mary Jane Van Dugan? - the liveliest woman -
Letter from Mrs. Sargent - Con at Wash. opened splendidly
though papers report is all Dr.? Mary brother & Mrs Tillots?
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her travels to La Porte City, Iowa, where she received a letter from Mrs. Sargent and met with various people.

entries.fullText:
Left - La Porte at ?30 A.M. - & went to Waterloo -
The Logan Hotel - slept till 9 O'clock - & then fussed and feathered? to heart's content - washing ?? - & cleaning a ???? to here & there -
Mrs. M. L. Burnham - leading temperance woman here - called in P. M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her travels to Waterloo, Iowa, where she met with Mrs. M. L. Burnham.

entries.fullText:
$20
Manchester, Ia -
S. G. Vanander
stopped at Horence Hotel
Mrs. Mary Babcock - a widow - one of proprietors -
Splendid audience
of 4 or 5 hundred - with 21@ c/o admission
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her travels to Manchester, Iowa, where she had a splendid audience.

entries.fullText:
$20
Hopkinton, Ia
T. H. McBride
Took to Jeleman Centre- 6 miles & stopped at Doctor & Mrs. Finlay - Mrs. C. F. Flint & daughter of
Hazel Green, sister ?, then to see and hear me- a very smart & well read woman - fine audience
entries.summaryText: Visited Jeleman Centre and Doctor & Mrs. Finlay, met Mrs. C. F. Flint and daughter of Hazel Green, and gave a lecture to a fine audience.

entries.fullText:
Elgin, Ia $20
H. C. Hammond
Team - 11 miles back to Dela??? Centre at 7.30 - insane woman - not 30 - on way to Independence asylum -
Stopped at Ind. from 11 to 4 P.M.
was guest of Mr. & Mrs. E. R. Carpenter - got new shoes by mail here from Leavenworth -
Letter from sister Mary - of 12th
all well at home & little ???? ????? since not ?????
entries.summaryText: Visited Dela??? Centre and Independence asylum, stopped at Ind., was a guest of Mr. & Mrs. E. R. Carpenter, and received a letter from sister Mary.

entries.fullText:
$30
West Union, Ia
C. H. Talmadge
stopped at Crescent House - very nice & pleasant
splendid audience
entries.summaryText: Stopped at Crescent House, had a splendid audience.

entries.fullText:
Remained at M. W. till 6 P. M, had calls from several ladies - nice
who claimed sympathy that husband punished her every time she acted independently - like going to my lecture - getting off some other thing - & soon told me she was a German Saloon keeper - then ???ing at hotel -
slept at Posthille?
entries.summaryText: Remained at M. W. till 6 P. M, had calls from several ladies, and slept at Posthille.

entries.fullText:
Stopped at Dr. Babcocks
his wife Emma J. Adams -
- just finished new parlors
bed in back parlor--& the
new paint & [??pn??s]
just perfect--
fine audience--& splendid
people--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stopped at Dr. Babcock's house in New Hampton, La. and admired the new parlors and paint. She spoke to a fine audience and met splendid people.

entries.fullText:
Spoke in Rev. Baldwin's
M.E. Church -- Social evening
fine audience again
-- Mrs Silsber & Mrs. Briggs
& many others of the [?] leads
Temp. women declared
themselves converted
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke at Rev. Baldwin's M.E. Church to a fine audience. Many people, including Mrs. Silsber and Mrs. Briggs, attended the social evening. Temp. women declared themselves converted.

entries.fullText:
Took train at noon
for Calmar -- met
Mrs. J.C. McKinney there
had nice visit -- & the
landlady Mrs. John Fergurson
started for a lecture & 50
people gathered--& I [?]--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony took a train to Calmar and met Mrs. J.C. McKinney. She had a nice visit and the landlady, Mrs. John Fergurson, started a lecture where 50 people gathered.

entries.fullText:
LeRoy Minn --
J.A. Henderson
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was in LeRoy, Minn and met J.A. Henderson.

entries.fullText:
-Mrs J.E. Paden - & (Miss A. Shultis-)
Called at Austin - teacher-
Austin - Minn - $30-
Sup’t Pub. schools Edward Bigelow
my old friend H. Atillia Albro -
Davidson - lives here - also her
daughter Mrs. L. A. Sherwood
- both gone east to Rochester -
- weather cold but pleasant -
- a sort of slow audience -
still appreciative - but all new
to them - it is marvelous
how little people have thought on
the woman question -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Austin, Minnesota and meets with Mrs J.E. Paden, Miss A. Shultis, Edward Bigelow, H. Atillia Albro, Davidson, and Mrs. L. A. Sherwood. She notes that the audience was slow but appreciative and that people have not thought much about the woman question.

entries.fullText:
Albert Lea Minn $30
M. Halvorson
Stopped Hall House - fine audience
Mr. Halvorson an educated
Liberal Norwegian -
Mrs. Hall doing her own cooking &
everything [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Albert Lea, Minnesota and stays at Hall House. She notes that the audience was fine and that Mr. Halvorson is an educated Liberal Norwegian.

entries.fullText:
Wells - Minn- W. W. Woodard
Good audience in
Congregational Church -
Mrs B. F. Smith - & Mrs
W. B. Dunn - prominent Temp. women
Mr Willie Duston - came
over from Blue Earth - to
take me across the county
with team 21 - miles
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Wells, Minnesota and speaks at the Congregational Church. She notes that there was a good audience and that she was taken across the county by Mr. Willie Duston.

entries.fullText:
Blue Earth - Minn
Carr Huntingdon
Splendid audience at the
Court House - Mr H. a
Democratic Ed - but honest
& always fighting the 'rings'
Willie Duston introduced
me - his mother a lovely woman
seldom see so many fine faced
women as here -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Blue Earth, Minnesota and speaks at the Court House. She notes that there was a splendid audience and that Mr. H. is a Democratic Ed who is honest and always fighting the 'rings'. She also notes that she was introduced by Willie Duston and that there were many fine faced women in attendance.

entries.fullText:
Lectured Temp & Social Purity
in Presbyterian Church
Splendid audience - & both the
Pres. & Methodist minister endorsed
my word - Took a 10 ct.
contribution at the door
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony lectured on Temp & Social Purity at Presbyterian Church in Blue Earth- Minn. Both the Pres. & Methodist minister endorsed her word. She took a 10 ct. contribution at the door.

entries.fullText:
W. P. Sherman
Willie Justen & sister
Minnie & friend
took me to W. Stopped
at Saffords Hotel - had
a fine audience - Mr.
B. F. Goodwin - Master
Workman - A. O. W. M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was taken to Winnebago Minn by W. P. Sherman, Willie Justen & sister, and Minnie & friend. She stopped at Saffords Hotel and had a fine audience. Mr. B. F. Goodwin, Master Workman - A. O. W. M. was present.

entries.fullText:
Left Winnebago as
at 7 A.M. & drove across the
country to [*St James*] Crystal Lake - 25 miles
Strong east wind & snowing
in open buggy - arrived Crystal
at noon- & took train at 3 P.M.
Mr. Oakley - the [?] at Crystal
Stopped with Mr & Mrs
Herrick - very pleasant home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Winnebago and drove across the country to Crystal Lake. She arrived at noon and took a train at 3 P.M. She stopped with Mr & Mrs Herrick, a very pleasant home.

entries.fullText:
St. James - Minn
G. H. Herrick
Mrs Lina Knickerbocker Clapp - sister
of Teacher R. in Rochester- wife of a
Baptist minister - Mrs N. P.
Bradford of Madelia Minn - & her
husband drove 9 miles to St. James -
Mrs Case - teacher - did not go to my
lecture - farm poverty - grasshoppers
the cause - it made sick after
lecture - to hear them tell how many of their
most earnest, intelligent people couldn’t go
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was in St. James - Minn. She met with G. H. Herrick, Mrs Lina Knickerbocker Clapp - sister of Teacher R. in Rochester- wife of a Baptist minister - Mrs N. P. Bradford of Madelia Minn - & her husband. Mrs Case - teacher - did not go to her lecture. Farm poverty - grasshoppers the cause - it made her sick after lecture - to hear them tell how many of their most earnest, intelligent people couldn’t go.

entries.fullText:
Z.E. Brown
Left U. James at 5 A.M.
Stopped at Clark Hotel - not more
than 'middling' - Mrs. Charlotte O.
Van Cleve - who stood [by?]Kate
Noonan in her trial for shooting
her seducer - called also Mrs.
Walker - [security?] of the Bethany
had about 500 audience - then
Pres. of the Z.M.C. introduced me -
Candace & Ann Thurston called
Candace Allen - lives here
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stayed at Clark Hotel in Minneapolis and met with Mrs. Charlotte O. Van Cleve and Candace Allen.

entries.fullText:
Stopped at the Leavitt's - had
nice little audience - had a
sweet letter from Abby Hutchinson
Anderson - Asa's daughter - lives 20 miles from ?'s
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stayed at L.W. Leavitt's place in Litchfield and received a letter from Abby Hutchinson Anderson.

entries.fullText:
Left ? at 2 P.M.
& arrives at M. at 6 P.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony traveled from an unknown location and arrived at M at 6 P.M.

entries.fullText:
Minneapolis - Temp. & Social
Purity - Association Hall - for ? of
Mrs. Charlotte O. Van Cleve's
Bethany Society - introduced me.
Mrs. Sarah I. Griswold of this city
had article in Press of this A.M. in false ?
of our National Wash. Con -

Had a packed house of 1000 -
& Mrs. Van Cleve said we heard
true and every word word was just
what she wanted the people to hear.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke at the Association Hall in Minneapolis for the Bethany Society and had a packed house of 1000 people.

entries.fullText:
Met the H [?] sisters at Hotel.
on return from losing the train.
Hudson Wis $30
Mrs. Horace Barlow
The Clark House finished up
by letting me be left from 10 train
So waited till 2 P.M -- Went to St-P.
& there hired team 20 -miles.
reached H. at 7 oclock -- too
tired for anything -- Mrs B. is
a Vassar graduate -- Viola
Boon - & full of ambition to be
independent -- had splendid audience
in the M.E. Church --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony met the H sisters at a hotel in Hudson Wis after losing her train and had a splendid audience in the M.E. Church.

entries.fullText:
Red Wing - Minn. $30
O.M. Hall
L.A. Hancock introduced me
Left Hudson at 8 A.M. &
drove to St. Paul -- took train at
[?]. & reached R.W. at 1.30 -- I
had a good rest once more
before lecture --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was introduced by L.A. Hancock in Red Wing, Minn after having a good rest before her lecture.

entries.fullText:
Mr J. P. Tiffany- lives Durand
he is grand son of Aunt Hannah
Madison- Grandmother Reads sister
Durand - Wis -
W.H.H. Matteson
Duncan McKenzie took me
across from Wabasha -- 22 miles --
arrived just 6 P.M. stopped
at Rev. M. Ridders -- his daughter
Augusta Ridder -- very attentive --
Mr Barry Temp. Lecturer there --
Capt. Wilson, Son T. B. & wife Julia --
Eliza T., & her friend Mrs Barron -- & the
two girls Angie & Sadie & ever so many
more over from Menominie 25 miles
splendid audience --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony met Mr. J. P. Tiffany in Durand, Wis and had a splendid audience with many people attending her lecture.

entries.fullText:
To fill A. A. Willetts place
he was sick & couldn’t
come
St Paul - Minn -
S. C. Williams --
Left at 7 A.M. -- arrived at
Wabasha 11 -- train late -- & 8 miles
below Hastings Engine run off track
& we were delayed 3 hours -- so it
was 7 evening when arrived St Paul --
stopped Metropolitan - Opera House
filled -- J. Ellen Foster came to Hotel
& staid with me -- was dreadfully
nervous & tired -- but got through
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony filled in for A. A. Willetts in St Paul, Minn and was joined by J. Ellen Foster who was nervous and tired but they both got through.

entries.fullText: Mrs M.A. Hazen left St. Paul at 11.25 - on West Wisconsin R. R. Mr. Wm Mead - Con - at Menominee Miss Eliza T. Wilson & her friend Mrs Henry D. Barron of St Croix Falls, Wis. - came on board - so visited instead of sleeping, as I had intended - Green Bay Trains waited 40 minutes for me - & I landed at A. at 7.40 - large audience again - but made a dreadfully tired speech.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Arcadia, Wisconsin, and gives a speech to a large audience.

entries.fullText: Left A. at 9.30 and stopped at Merrillan all day till 6 P.M. Slept three hours & wrote some - took train to Madison - arrived 1 A.M. & went to Capitol House.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stops in Merrillan, Wisconsin, before continuing on to Madison.

entries.fullText: At Madison Wis - at Capitol House - slept till near 10 A.M. - then took my breakfast at dinner time 1 P.M But am too tired & stupid to go to see Mrs. Elizabeth Ford Proudfit - or to see Mrs Professor Bascom - ([D???] was brought back to R. from his trip to Dunkirk - been gone from Thursday A.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is too tired to visit friends in Madison, Wisconsin.

entries.fullText: Baraboo - Wis [?] [?] [?] Wm A. Willis called & dined with my old friend Elizabeth Ford - her sister Maria, with her - Took train at 4 P.M. Bay horses & & carriage like brother D.R.'s - Stopped with Dr. Moses & Mrs Emmie Davis - Martha McClure sister of Hannah McClure & friends of Samuel Bragg of Centre Falls lives alone here - is an artist - The doctors people old abolitionists & spoke in Ichabod Codding's old church -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Baraboo, Wisconsin, and dines with her friend Elizabeth Ford before giving a speech at Ichabod Codding's old church.

entries.fullText:
Delevan - Wisc
F.W. Sturtevant
Madison - Wis -
Mrs Andrew Proudfit -
Elizabeth Ford - that was -
lecture abandoned because of Jon Smith
reception evening- Pres't & Mrs. Bascom -
& Mrs. Hoyt to tea with Mrs. Proudfit -
- delightful house - a superior woman
daughter Julia Hopkins lovely - & sister
Maria quiet as ever -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her visit to Delevan and Madison, Wisconsin, where she attended a lecture and a reception and met several people.

entries.fullText:
Delevan - Wis -
F.W. Sturtevant
stopped at the Wis. State
Deaf & Dumb Institute -
Pres. DeMotte & wife -
she a music teacher married him
with six children - a Miss Smith
teacher there - splendid audience -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her visit to Delevan, Wisconsin, where she stopped at the Wisconsin State Deaf & Dumb Institute and met with Pres. DeMotte and a Miss Smith.

entries.fullText:
Darlington Wis -
Editor - W. J. Wrigglesworth
introduced by Hon Henry G. Magoon
didn’t arrive until near
7 o’clock - dreadfully tired -
met Lady on train who had
been down to Warren to hear Mrs.
Stanton last night - too bad to
be so near each other & not meet -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her visit to Darlington, Wisconsin, where she met with Editor W. J. Wrigglesworth and Hon Henry G. Magoon and encountered a lady on the train who had been to hear Mrs. Stanton.

entries.fullText:
Mineral Point - Wis -
Dr. G. W. Field -
Am 58 Today - letter from sister Mary &
brother D.R. about what to do with Dannie - It’s dreadful
to have a boy who has no self respect - Mrs. Gage writes
about starting paper in New York
First a packed audience
people drove in through mud
14 miles - quite a number &
staid all night at Hotel -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her visit to Mineral Point, Wisconsin, where she met with Dr. G. W. Field and received a letter from her sister Mary and brother D.R. about what to do with Dannie. She also mentions Mrs. Gage's plan to start a paper in New York and the packed audience at her event.

entries.fullText:
Left M. P. at 5.45 -- arrived Lena
at 10 A.M. -- Had sick time --
just a taste of lemon pie. Seemed
the irritating cause -- Had fearfully
small audience -- Not over 60 or 70
& was too sick to speak -- Still
went through with it --

Sent a night dispatch to sister Mary
saying --Try again or send Doctor Hixon --
Dont send home nor refuge --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Lena, Illinois, but was too sick to speak to the small audience. She sent a night dispatch to her sister Mary.

entries.fullText:
Got about 11 A.M -- had bowl
of oat meal gruel at 9 A.M --
Don't feel strait yet -- It's such
a constant worry about little
Dannie & dear sister Marys
perfect exhaustion over him --
got letter & C.B.Q. & R.I. passes
from brother D.R. and letter with
$1000 note from brother Merritt --
& Accident policy for $25 a week --
$25,000 for death -- from Frank
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stayed at the Watkins Hotel in Lena, Illinois, and received letters and financial support from her brothers.

entries.fullText:
Left Lena at 11.45 & reached
Mendota 2.45 A.M --
A. J. Grover -- Room 41 Major Poleck
Chicago on board train to Galesburg
good visit -- Miss Kate B.
Ross - (Elocutionist) introduced
me handsomely - she wants to
be a W. S. lecturer -- at least
a 500 audience --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Lena, Illinois, and met with A. J. Grover and Kate B. Ross on her way to Abingdon, Illinois.

entries.fullText:
stopped with Mr & Mrs. K.- their
daughter Ella M. Kreider
small but good audience
a letter of 16th from sister
Mary -- not settled upon course
with Dan yet --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stayed with Mr. and Mrs. K. in Prairie City, Illinois, and received a letter from her sister Mary regarding Dan.

entries.fullText:
left P. City at 6 A.M. - the day
a regular April rain -
spoke in Court House - small
audience- 80- or so - but more
than any one would have thought
possible to get out - Paid back
$5. to Mr. Shannon - to help him to
be left - even -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left P. City at 6 A.M. and spoke in Court House to a small audience in Palmyra, Mo. She paid back $5 to Mr. Shannon.

entries.fullText:
Letters from sister M. & brother
Merritt - nice letter from Dannie saying
he was going to try harder than ever to
be a good boy -
Mud & rain beyond anything
Still a good audience -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony received letters from her sister M. and brother Merritt. She also received a nice letter from Dannie who said he was going to try harder than ever to be a good boy. She spoke to a good audience in Fayette, Mo despite the mud and rain.

entries.fullText:
Impossible to reach- so
Telegraphed to abandon lecture-
it is 18 miles from Wentzville &
roads impassible -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was unable to reach Troy, Mo due to impassible roads and telegraphed to abandon lecture.

entries.fullText:
Planters Hotel SATURDAY 23, Mrs. W. S. Gordon Gordon’s
Columbia - Mo. - Garth Hall
Dem. Ed.- Wm. F. Switzler -
Judge P. Bliss - at whose house
I stopped at St Jo. 1865 - is Prof.
of Law in state University here
Splendid audience - one of my
happiest of weeks - noted solid for
16th Aniv
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke at Garth Hall in Columbia, Mo to a splendid audience. She stayed at Planters Hotel and noted the week as one of her happiest. She also mentioned the 16th anniversary of something.

entries.fullText:
At Columbia - dined at Mrs &
Dr Gilman’s - bright woman -
Judge & Mrs Bliss board there -
Judge Kelley, there - [?] P.M.
Major Rollins &
came with Hack - saying Court
House was packed to hear me -
found Hall locked & then went - to
C. K. made fires - Major R. Introduced
my speech - & I made a
desultory talk on woman's moral
powerlessness - all seemed very
pleased & 7 subscribers For The B. B.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony dined at Mrs. and Dr. Gilman's in Columbia and gave a speech on woman's moral powerlessness, gaining 7 subscribers for The B.B.

entries.fullText:
J. C. Greenman
stopped at Judge Edwin
Drapers - wife a most lovely
cultured woman, her father -
Pettigrew- 97, - with them their
daughter Susan Draper after - Notary
Public - & Music Teacher-
- good audience.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stopped at Judge Edwin Drapers in Louisianna, MO and spoke to a good audience.

entries.fullText:
Clarksville Mo-
N. M. Pettengill
Charles E. Carroll - nephew
of Mrs Lemon of Mattoon Ind.
met me Depot - Splendid
audience -
Mrs Fanny Harris of
Bowling Green - largest farmer
in county- has 800 acres
all under cultivation
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke to a splendid audience in Clarksville, MO and met Mrs. Fanny Harris, the largest farmer in the county.

entries.fullText:
[*LaGrange - Mo-
R. M. Wallace*]
Hannibal Mo-
Wm H. Homans
Mrs Wentworth formerly [Canijohanie?]
called— Mrs J. T. R. Hayward
called- Met Sister Hannah at
Denver two years ago - real
earnest- W. L. Morman-
Small audience -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke to a small audience in Hannibal, MO and met with various people including Mrs. Wentworth and Sister Hannah.

entries.fullText:
arrived at 8 A. M -
found letters from Rochester
Fort Scott & Leavenworth- all
hopeful - Had a most restless
audience - young girls & boys talking & laughing
at last found it partly owing to cold
room - (made poorest of each
seemed as if I was touching nothing
-- it was myself laughing - quite likely
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in La Grange, MO and found letters from Rochester, Fort Scott, and Leavenworth. She had a restless audience of young girls and boys who were talking and laughing, but she eventually found success.

entries.fullText:
Telegram from brother D.R. cast
the die - I took H. & St. Jo. train for
Leavenworth - rain came on - train
got behind - had to stop at
Cameron - to stay over & take
Sat. A.M. Rock Island train
larger number of Ill. people going
to Kansas--Mrs. Whitehead going
to Afton P.O. - 14 miles from Witcheta
- it is a perfect beginning into
Kansas this spring - Stopped
at Combe's Hotel -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony received a telegram from her brother D.R. and took a train to Leavenworth. She had to stop at Cameron due to rain and stayed at Combe's Hotel. She noted that many people from Illinois were going to Kansas, including Mrs. Whitehead.

entries.fullText:
Arrived Leavenworth
of R.I. [?] train--brother
D.R. at Depot--Sister Annie
& Maude & Susie & Dannie all well--
drizzly day--Major [Threene?]
given release of P.O. on Friday--
& brother D.R. working it through
with Frank & Eugene--$500-
worth of [3 at rawls] gone--making
in all $1,800--stolen --or lost
this year--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Leavenworth and met with her brother D.R. and other family members. She noted that Major [Threene?] was given a release of P.O. and that her brother D.R. was working on something with Frank and Eugene. She also mentioned that $500 worth of something was gone, making it a total of $1,800 lost or stolen that year.

entries.fullText:
Pretty pleasant day--at
Leavenworth--Mrs. Margaret T.
Adams--formerly Phelps of
Peoria Ill--& sister of Gov. Ed
McCook's wife--Mary Thompson
McCook of [D?]--dined
at brother D.R.'s also brother Eugene
& nephew Frank Mosher--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a pleasant day in Leavenworth and dined with Mrs. Margaret T. Adams, who was formerly Phelps of Peoria Ill and sister of Gov. Ed McCook's wife Mary Thompson McCook. She also dined with her brother D.R., Eugene, and nephew Frank Mosher.

entries.fullText:
Left Leavenworth at 12 noon
met on train Mrs Susie Miller
of Memphis Tenn--wife of
G. T. Phillips--of Denver Col--
stopped Ogden House--
Council Bluffs--arrived 11 oclock
& left at 5 oclock Tuesday
A.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves Leavenworth and meets Mrs. Susie Miller on the train.

entries.fullText:
Harlan Iowa
D.M. Wyland
Wm. Stulsman met me at
Avoca & took me the 15 miles
& spring broke--& tied up for
half the [morning?]--stopped at
Mr Nicks--a lawyer--
nice family--got long letter from
Mrs Gage--also one from
sister Mary--little Dannie &
niece Louise--Dannie says
he didn't succeed in being a good
boy all the week--but will try again.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony's spring breaks on the way to Harlan, Iowa. She receives letters from Mrs. Gage and her sister Mary.

entries.fullText:
Council Bluff--Iowa
J. Dohaney & D.R. Witter
Stopped with Mrs. Ameila &
Dexter C. Bloomer--
Small audiences & gone
Homes--don't like it
Marie Nichols--married Kelley
lives here--& Willie Mills
son of D.C.B. Mills of Syracuse
called on me
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stays in Council Bluffs, Iowa and meets with J. Dohaney, D.R. Witter, Mrs. Ameila, Dexter C. Bloomer, Marie Nichols, and Willie Mills.

entries.fullText:
Missouri Valley--Iowa
Jas G. Kreider
Mr & Mrs M. Holbrook--
now live here at M.V.--they
drove over from Magnolia--
7 years ago to hear me--
almost no audience--no recent
notice given--Spent day to
5 P.M. with Mrs. Bloomer--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Missouri Valley, Iowa and spends the day with Mrs. Bloomer. There is almost no audience at her speaking event.

entries.fullText: Small meeting - severe rain - [Mr. & Mrs. Holbrook fine here. Didn't come over until 6 P.M. train] - Mrs. La Porte introduced me here
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a small meeting in Logan, Iowa, despite severe rain. She meets with Mrs. J. T. Stern, Mr. & Mrs. Holbrook, and Mrs. La Porte, who introduces her to the group.

entries.fullText: Smith M. Child + Rachel Lockwood Child - made me a pleasant home - Mrs. Child has lectured on Home Education - Mrs. Child introduced me - full house - but small hall-- Mr. Reiders form engagement are + had sell - he put the price down to 25 and 25 cts - & none of their court tours can pay at that -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Dunlap, Iowa, and stays with Smith M. Child and Rachel Lockwood Child. She attends a lecture on Home Education by Mrs. Child and speaks to a full house in a small hall. Mr. Reiders lowers the price of his engagement to 25 and 25 cents.

entries.fullText: Spoke at 2 P. M - in Lehan's hall - 40 seats - but rough boards - gave leinherow[?] talk - full house Got letter here from Mrs Hooker from Riggs Hotel - where the dome - remained since Jan. Can - just as full of assurance of ???? success - as she was six years ago
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks at Lehan's hall in Dunlap, Iowa, to a full house despite the rough boards and limited seating. She receives a letter from Mrs. Hooker, who is staying at the Riggs Hotel and remains confident in her success.

entries.fullText: Mrs Matthews called on me thought Mr. P. was dying out - had read on J newspaper reports - taken no W. S. paper Had a splendid audience - first time in a new - My manager took Lunch home - without [?] my 3/5 gross receipts for lost from lectures - waited at hotel appealing time after lecture + [?] [?] A. M. - topic offering
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks to a splendid audience in Dennison, Iowa, for the first time in a new location. She meets with Mrs. Matthews, who is concerned about Mr. P.'s declining health. Her manager takes her lunch home and loses 3/5 of her gross receipts from lectures.

entries.fullText:
W. N. Becker
Telegraphed Mr. Kreider - why he didn't
pay me last night - guess I've lost
it- about $80 -

Met here at Hotel Mr
McMartin - has 1000 acre farm
14 miles out - calls it Lib's farm -
his [?] has 1000 acres 2 miles
out of Dunlap -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony telegraphs Mr. Kreider about not receiving payment and meets with Mr. McMartin who has a farm near Dunlap.

entries.fullText:
A.B. Wright
Stopped with Mr & Mrs Daniel
Wayne - Mrs M. W. Johnson
the one W. S. Woman for years -
the ministers wife Mrs A. M. Palmer
& Mrs Wayne strong temp. but not suff.
Got Postal from Kreider say
sent money Chicago to day - Everything
correct - & Mrs Childs telegram that
he said he'd sent money order from Denver
yesterday - Got telegram from
Postmaster No Order sent from Denver
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stays with Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Wayne and receives a telegram from Kreider about sending money and a telegram from Mrs. Child about a money order from Denver.

entries.fullText:
J.W. Harney
Got Telegram from Slayton--
has received no money from
Krieder--so guess all is up--
but what can the fellow mean
to ruin himself for so small an amt
--Jefferson next station
beyond (?) this lives uncle H.A's
daughter Eliza Porter Green
got letter from Sister M.
& $1000 draft for Merritt--by Monroe Co
Bank Deposit--for M. to [?]
mortgages
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a telegram from Slayton about not receiving money from Kreider and a letter from Sister M. with a $1000 draft for Merritt.

entries.fullText:
L. [Darwin?]
Another Postal here dated 14th say
sent $48.75 to Slayton--Kreider
Also letter from Mrs. Child say
Kreider sent $38 to Slayton
still I doubt--if he has it is only
1/2 of what he owes me--
Stopped here with Mrs E.
J. Potter--her sister Mrs
J. B. Ferm sent a 250 petition to
Mrs Spencer--splendid audience
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a postal and letter about Kreider sending money to Slayton and stays with Mrs. E. J. Potter who received a petition from her sister for Mrs. Spencer.

entries.fullText:
Left Nevada at noon-
arrived Fort Dodge 4:30-
Mr. Mrs. Davis of Cedar Falls-
keep Duncan Hotel here -
Mr. D. an old friend of Sister Annies
- Lovely day - but was
sick enough of room
at Hotel - so gloomy -
felt I couldn't stay in
it over Sunday - till I
found Mrs. Davis kept it
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives at Fort Dodge and stays at the Duncan Hotel. She is unhappy with her room and finds out that Mr. and Mrs. Davis keep a hotel in the area.

entries.fullText:
At Fort Dodge--&
Juneau Hotel--perfectly
lovely 'May' day--wrote
long letter to my old clerk
Lib Brown--now Chatfield--
in answer to hers of Feb. 14th in
memory of my 58th birth day--
A.E. Dickinson has been with her
all winter--& I told her the reason
I did not write her at time of illness
was because I thought any word
from would add to her [?]--
called on Mrs. Adaline M. Swain--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends a lovely day at the Juneau Hotel in Fort Dodge. She writes a long letter to her old clerk, Lib Brown, and visits Mrs. Adaline M. Swain.

entries.fullText:
Webster City--Iowa
D.P. Maryatt
Mrs Swain accompanied me to
W. City--Mrs C.L. Wilson took
us & her sister Mrs Marion Maite
a drive with her ponies--the day
just a perfect one--
Hamilton hotel had dreadful
fair audience--Y.M.C.A. boys
[manager?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Webster City, Iowa with Mrs. Swain. They go on a drive with Mrs. C.L. Wilson and her sister. The Hamilton hotel has a poor audience.

people: Mr and Mrs J . W. Spencer
entries.fullText:
F.L. Dodge Editor
Mr and Mrs J . W. Spencer
escorted me to Church -
thunder shower came on
& made everybody nervous -
got letter from Mrs Williams -
Took train at 11.45 after
lecture - raining hard
& steady - wrote Mrs. Sargent &
Mrs Lockwood - Judge Edmunds
your adverse report on women
on Supreme Court ---
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends church in Parkersburg Iowa and receives a letter from Mrs. Williams. She also takes a train and writes letters to Mrs. Sargent and Mrs. Lockwood regarding Judge Edmunds' report on women in the Supreme Court.

entries.fullText:
Spent day till 3.30
P.M. in Independence
drove out & visited the
Insane Assylum - Dr
Reynolds - the superintendent -
Sad, sad, but oh so much better
to house them there [massed] &
cared for - spent night
at Postville
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits the Insane Asylum in Independence and spends the night in Postville.

entries.fullText:
Waukon - Iowa -
May & Hancock
Went by team from Postville -
lovely spring day - stopped with
Mr. & Mrs. G. W. Hays - daughter
Josephine - a lovely girl - [?] good home
fine audience -
Have had cold since Tuesday
A.M. from Webster City horrid room
& worst kind of bed - but to night the
first that it troubled me in speaking
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Waukon, Iowa with May and Hancock. She stays with Mr. & Mrs. G. W. Hays and speaks to a fine audience.

entries.fullText:
Luana Iowa
A. M. Bronson
Team back to Postville - Cars
at 3 P.M. - - Mrs Bronson met
me depot - & a delightful
home they have - daughters Belle &
Laura & son George - the day
uncomfortably warm - lovely - turned
cold at night - had fine audience -
coughed some - made hard work
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony returns to Postville from Luana, Iowa. She stays with A. M. Bronson and speaks to a fine audience despite coughing.

entries.fullText:
Spent day at Luana -
with the Bronsons - they are
universalists - alone here -
went to M. E. Church - heard
Presiding Elder preach old time
sermon - it was Quarterly meeting -
preached on hell in eve'g - didn't
go - but Belle did & reported it
the old time furnace of fire & brimstone
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the day at Luana with the Bronsons, went to the M. E. Church and heard the Presiding Elder preach an old time sermon on hell.

entries.fullText:
Left Luana at 3.30. P.M.
stayed all night at
Haskell Hotel - at
Lone Rock -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Luana and stayed overnight at Haskell Hotel in Lone Rock.

entries.fullText:
Richland Centre - Wis.
A.H. Crouskop
Mrs. J. W. Leybrand - of this place -
called & brot letter of Dec. 1863 of Loyal League
she circulated petitions & boy got badge -
Had splendid audience
Judge B. Miner introduced
me - stopped at
Tryon's hotel-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visited Richland Centre, met with A.H. Crouskop and Mrs. J. W. Leybrand who brought a letter from Dec. 1863 of Loyal League, had a splendid audience and was introduced by Judge B. Miner.

entries.fullText:
Jonesville - Wis
C.W. Baker
Rev. Jones - minister
Mrs M. A. Newman & sons
& old gentleman. College
graduated rode across his
county 20 miles to hear me
Mr J. H. P. Porter - Cooksville
Wis-- terrible rain--small
audience
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visited Jonesville, met with C.W. Baker, Rev. Jones, Mrs M. A. Newman and sons, and J. H. P. Porter who rode across his county 20 miles to hear her speak, but had a small audience due to terrible rain.

entries.fullText:
Left Myers Hotel-
at Janesville- at 7
A. M - arrived
Chicago - called
Slayton at Gossage's
House - then to Aunt
A. E. S.'s - Wendell
had letter, Eugene ill two weeks
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Myers Hotel in Janesville and arrived in Chicago. She called on Slayton at Gossage's House and then went to Aunt A. E. S.'s. Wendell had a letter saying Eugene was ill for two weeks.

entries.fullText:
Seneca - Ill
D. H. Underhill
Dark & Rainy night -
Letter from Cousin
Ira House - of Ottawa
inviting me to visit them -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was in Seneca, Illinois and received a letter from Cousin Ira House of Ottawa inviting her to visit them.

entries.fullText:
Oswego - Ill
F. O. Tarbox
Stopped Ottawa 2 hours -
Cousin Ira at Depot - drove me
to his house - raining & muddy
arrived Oswego at 5:20 - stopped
with Mr & Mrs J. N. Hall
nice people - letter from Sister
Mary telling of Dannie's run a way
last Monday - it is just killing -
Mrs Josie T. Hall
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was in Oswego, Illinois and stopped in Ottawa for two hours. Cousin Ira met her at the depot and drove her to his house. She stayed with Mr. & Mrs. J. N. Hall and received a letter from Sister Mary telling of Dannie's run away last Monday.

entries.fullText:
Took team to Aurora - 6
miles & took 8 train to
Chicago - dined with
Wendell at his boarding house
all very nice - A lady teacher
Mrs Smallwood a real mother
to him - It is just a
year ago to day that dear Sister
Hannah wrote her last letter to me.
saying 'I breathe easier because it is the
last day of March - but oh only a
short six weeks more left to her -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony took a team to Aurora and then took a train to Chicago. She dined with Wendell at his boarding house and met Mrs. Smallwood, a lady teacher who was like a mother to him. She also reflected on the passing of her dear Sister Hannah a year ago.

entries.fullText:
Left Chicago at 10:30 - but [???]
and waited till 2:30 - & returned to L-
found Parker Pillsbury at
the hotel - glad to see him -
[but] was too tired to visit - so
rushed to bed till lecture time
a fine audience - Miss
is a teacher at L. and lives
at Earlville
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Leland, Illinois and meets with Laura E. Hard and Parker Pillsbury before giving a lecture to a fine audience.

entries.fullText:
J. E. Bennett
Miss H. Mr. P. & self went to
Earl on 8 freight - had a
good visit with cousin
Susan Hoxie Richardson
Mr P also - & left on
4 train for Plano - stopped
at Mr George Stewards - [aunt?]
Nancy
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Plano, Illinois and spends time with J. E. Bennett, Miss H., Mr. P., and cousin Susan Hoxie Richardson before stopping at Mr. George Stewards.

entries.fullText:
Left Plano at 9.30--saw Mr
P. & Cousin Susan at Earl
Depot--a [?] reached
Wyanet at 1 P.M.--and
slept a good sleep this P.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves Plano, Illinois and sees Mr. P. and Cousin Susan at Earl Depot before arriving at Wyanet and sleeping well.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Anna Norris Rendall
met me at Arlington & took me
to her father's Farm House--Isaac
Norris-she a widow with
lovely boy of 10--Georgie [Cayvan?] a
[ke?] & Miss Knox the teacher [?]
the brother Clarkson Norris--
splendid audience-
Letter from Sister Mary--note from Dannie
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits La Moille, Illinois and is taken to Isaac Norris' Farm House by Mrs. Anna Norris Rendall where she meets Georgie [Cayvan?], Miss Knox, and Clarkson Norris before giving a lecture to a splendid audience. She also receives a letter from Sister Mary and a note from Dannie.

entries.fullText: Mr Moriss drove me out to see his stock - splendid - Anna with same team - The Tuckahoes drove me to 12 - train - never reached V. till 8 P.M. & then found Slayton had pledged me for Single Woman - so stammered through the fragmentary manuscript once more - small audience -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Vermont Ill and sees Mr. Moriss' stock. She then takes a train to Vermont and arrives late to a small audience due to a misunderstanding with Slayton.

entries.fullText: One year ago this day of the week - I reached Leavenworth & my dear dear Sister Hannah - but what a break her death has made in my poor heart - none can tell -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony reflects on the anniversary of her sister Hannah's death while in Lewiston - Ill.

entries.fullText: Lewistown - spent day in writing letters -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day writing letters while in Lewistown.

entries.fullText: Left L. at 6 - breakfasted at Canton - arrived B. at [?] - rained hard - no lecture - Letter from Sister Mary - Daninie heard from in Ohio - & wanting help to get back Stopped at Mr Dennings
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Bushnell Ill and receives a letter from Sister Mary. She also hears from Daninie who is in Ohio and needs help getting back.

entries.fullText:
reached New B. at 4 P.M.-
Miss Amanda Stager- the
Court Superintendent at the
Lytle's- fine audience
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony reached New Boston and had a fine audience with Miss Amanda Stager, the Court Superintendent at the Lytle's.

entries.fullText:
Mother got another terrible
fall today the 10th
Dined at Mr Ballards
& went to Burlington
stopped at Gorham Hotel
Mary Osgood & sister
Julia & brother live here-
but couldn't learn of their
place to call-
Ms Boecklin of B. a good
suffragist
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had dinner at Mr. Ballard's and went to Burlington, stopping at Gorham Hotel. She also met Mary Osgood, Julia, and Ms. Boecklin, a good suffragist.

entries.fullText:
arrived 1 P.M. stopped
Hendu house - had fair
audience- but the law
Mr West, Denning, Sparks
&c- are Liberal League-
which frightens the religionists.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived at Bushnell, Illinois and had a fair audience at Hendu house, but the presence of Mr. West, Denning, Sparks, and others from the Liberal League frightened the religionists.

entries.fullText:
Left B at 4:20- arrive 9 A.M.
Mrs C leading Temp. woman-
letters from Sister Mary & brother
Merritt- called at insane asylum
& on Joseph and Ruth Dugdale
Had a 7 or 8 hundred audience
in 'Red Ribbon Hall' - Sunday
'Red Ribbon League-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left B and arrived at Mt. Pleasant, Iowa. She met with Mrs. C, who is a leading Temperance woman, and received letters from Sister Mary and brother Merritt. She also visited the insane asylum and Joseph and Ruth Dugdale. She had a large audience at the 'Red Ribbon Hall' on Sunday for the 'Red Ribbon League'.

entries.fullText:
H. L. Howard
Fine audience though threatened rain very much
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about H. L. Howard and a fine audience in Sheffield.

entries.fullText: At Sheffield went to hear Rev Chester Covill preach Unitarian - & then rode over to Buda in rain with him - his wife a lovely woman- two young girl teachers at house-very promising
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a Unitarian sermon in Sheffield and then travels to Buda with Rev Chester Covill and two young girl teachers.

entries.fullText: Stopped Mrs Sherwoods Hotel & Mrs Mattson But [?] better than to continue the lie any longer- Beecher still swears she is innocent of the great transgression- when & what will be the end of his [Bron?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about stopping at Mrs Sherwoods Hotel and Mrs Mattson in Prophetstown and mentions Beecher's denial of guilt.

entries.fullText: Left P. at 11 A.M. - met Clark Norris & he took me off at La Moille & to his Father's- where I spent pleasant P.M. & night--This A.M. Papers out with confession of Mrs Tilton- shocking to own she has been perjuring herself for four years
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony meets Clark Norris and spends the night at his father's house in La Moille. The next day, she reads about Mrs Tilton's confession of perjury in the papers.

entries.fullText: Mrs Kendall took me across to Princeton- with her Tuckahoe ponies- & dined with the Lovejoys- had most satisfactory talk with Mrs Lovejoy of her and Sophia's 1870 winter at Brooklyn- both clearly sour & talked the improprieties of the pastor's visits- took C B & Q Express at 2 P.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony dined with the Lovejoys in Princeton and had a satisfactory talk with Mrs. Lovejoy about her and Sophia's 1870 winter in Brooklyn.

entries.fullText: Quitman Mo E. M. Manning M.D. Arrived Marysville Mo at 7 A.M. took team to Q- 12 miles- letter from nephew Frank saying his knees had given out couldn't get up nor sit down- good audience- & drove back to Marysville after lecture- arriving at 2:30 A.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Quitman, MO and gave a lecture to a good audience before driving back to Marysville.

entries.fullText: Took train at 7:30 A.M. - arrived Atchison at 10- failed to find Heischer- the man who has 10 lectures for Kansas in May- dined at Otis House- and reached Leavenworth at 5 P.M.- found Eugene very ill with pneumonia- & Frank just able to walk- when once on his feet- but falling down with least jog from ballance
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony failed to find Heischer in Atchison and found Eugene very ill with pneumonia in Leavenworth.

entries.fullText: Mrs Judge Horton came in P.M. and sister Annie took us out to Mt [Mermiu?] - + there was the green mound over all that was mortal of my dear dear sister Hannah- a year ago now she was suffering- oh how terribly
entries.summaryText: Mrs Judge Horton and sister Annie took us out to Mt [Mermiu?].

entries.fullText: Theodore Tilton lectured in Opera House this ev'g- called at brother D.R.'s after lecture- he has grown fearfully old- says he knew nothing of Elizabeth's going to make her confession
entries.summaryText: Theodore Tilton lectured in Opera House and visited brother D.R. after the lecture.

entries.fullText:
Took 7.30 train for
Fort Scott - had two
hours at Kansas City -
called on Dr Jennie C. Hilderbrad
arrived Fort Scott at six 6. M -
found all well but Lucy E -
& she is still very feeble - though
better - Dannie arrived
last Friday - they sent money
to pay him from st Louis
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Fort Scott, stopping in Kansas City to visit Dr. Jennie C. Hilderbrad. She finds everyone well except for Lucy E, who is still feeble. Dannie also arrives, with money sent from St. Louis to pay him.

entries.fullText:
Took 10.20 train
back to Leavenworth
with intention to start
home Wednesday - but
Eugene couldn't be
started - so staid on
& on -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony took a train to Leavenworth and stayed there because Eugene couldn't be started.

entries.fullText:
Got letters from Mrs
Williams & Mrs Gage
saying the Ballot
Box was transferred
to Mrs Gage & Syracuse -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony received letters from Mrs Williams and Mrs Gage stating that the Ballot Box was transferred to Mrs Gage and Syracuse.

entries.fullText: MAY, FRIDAY 31. 1878.
JUNE, SATURDAY 1.

Rev. Morris 8th
anniversary - platform &
pulpit beautifully decorated with
flowers - an excellent rehearsal
& review of the 8 years - had
attended 75 funerals - 48 of them
of his own congregation & 28 - adults
& helping in church -
entries.summaryText: Celebration of Rev. Morris' 8th anniversary with a review of the past 8 years and attendance at 75 funerals.

entries.fullText: MONDAY 3.
JUNE, TUESDAY 4. 1878.
WEDNESDAY 5.
JUNE, THURSDAY 6. 1878.

FRIDAY 7.
Niece Maggie McLean
Baker returned from
Cincinnatti this A.M. -
entries.summaryText: Niece Maggie McLean Baker returned from Cincinnatti.

entries.fullText: JUNE, Saturday 8. 1878
SUNDAY 9.

Brother A. left for
Washington Point on the
7.20 A.M. train
Niece Maggie is
33 years old today
entries.summaryText: Brother A. left for Washington Point and Niece Maggie turned 33 years old.

entries.fullText:
Wrote 6 or 8 letters
to day for 3d Decade celebration
entries.summaryText: Wrote letters for 3d Decade celebration.

entries.fullText: William Cullen Bryant the Poet & Editor died this A. M. at 5.40 - almost 84 - Sent six letters for 3d Decade Con - today -
entries.summaryText: William Cullen Bryant, the poet and editor, died this morning at almost 84 years old. The author sent six letters for 3d Decade Con.

entries.fullText:
Left R. at 4.45 for Mrs. Gage's
Fayetteville -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left for Mrs. Gage's in Fayetteville.

entries.fullText:
Returned home from Fayetteville
Called at Amy Posts -
found Lydia Mott's sister
Phebe Willis Stern -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony returns home from Fayetteville and visits Amy Posts where she meets Lydia Mott's sister, Phebe Willis Stern.
Susan B. Anthony writes nothing on this day.

entries.fullText:
Brother Eugene
came, unexpectedly, from
Marion, Wayne Co. to day,
looking very well indeed -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony's brother Eugene visits unexpectedly from Marion, Wayne Co. and is looking well.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary's School closed
to day -- Maria Collins
daughter of cousin Hannah [Halper?]
called - also Joseph's daughter
entries.summaryText: Sister Mary's School closed, visitors Maria Collins, cousin Hannah's daughter and Joseph's daughter.

entries.fullText:
Wrote Mrs. May E. Butler
Clay Centre- Kansas - offering
her 50 per cent to canvas for the
National Citizen & Ballot Box -
very warm day -
entries.summaryText: Wrote to Mrs. May E. Butler in Clay Centre, Kansas offering her 50% to canvas for the National Citizen & Ballot Box on a very warm day.

entries.fullText:
Dear Sister Guelma's
60th Birth-day - What a blank there
is - no Guelma - no Hannah - no Father -
entries.summaryText: Reflecting on Sister Guelma's 60th birthday and the absence of Guelma, Hannah, and Father.

entries.fullText:
Sarah A. Sherman
arrived 10 P.M. train
and stopped with us -
entries.summaryText: Sarah A. Sherman arrived and stayed with us.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Gage came
Tuesday evening
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Gage arrived Tuesday evening.

entries.fullText:
Had preliminary meeting
at Mrs Hallowells -
entries.summaryText: Had preliminary meeting at Mrs. Hallowell's.

entries.fullText:
National W.S.A. Business
meeting - 10 A.M. - Unitarian Church
The hardest ordeal for me
was the abolition of Resolut
Cong. Com. which all felt must
be done - -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a National W.S.A. Business meeting and discusses the abolition of Resolut Cong. Com.

entries.fullText:
Celebration 30th Anniversary of
the Woman's Rights Movement -
Unitarian Church Rochester -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a celebration for the 30th Anniversary of the Woman's Rights Movement in Rochester.

entries.fullText:
- Miss M. A. Thomson
came with me - to spend a
week -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is joined by Miss M. A. Thomson to spend a week together.

entries.fullText:
Dr Lozier sick
with Cholera Morbus
at the House of
refuge all this
week
entries.summaryText: Dr Lozier is sick with Cholera Morbus at the House of refuge all this week.

entries.fullText:
Miss Thomson went to
Syracuse - and to
Fayetteville to visit Mrs
Gage - took a carriage
& drove out East Avenue
a two hours - before
she left at 10.15 -
entries.summaryText: Miss Thomson visits Syracuse and Fayetteville to see Mrs. Gage and drives out East Avenue for two hours.

entries.fullText:
Visited the Girls
Reformatory - took
dinner there - and
spoke to both boys &
girls in the Chapel -
Mrs Lozier better
entries.summaryText: Visits the Girls Reformatory, speaks to both boys and girls in the Chapel, and notes that Mrs. Lozier is better.

entries.fullText:
Eugene left for
Easton Wash. Co.
entries.summaryText: Eugene left for Easton Wash. Co.

entries.fullText:
Louise went up to
niece Maggies to spend
a two weeks -
entries.summaryText: Louise went to spend two weeks with niece Maggie.

entries.fullText: AUGUST, SATURDAY 3. 1878.
SUNDAY 4.

Sister May left
for her trip to Montreal
Quebec - Portland - White
Mountains - Old Orchard
Beach - Camp meet'g - Boston
New York & Ocean Grove,
Miss Annie H. Collins with
her -
entries.summaryText: Sister May left for a trip to various locations with Miss Annie H. Collins.

entries.fullText: TUESDAY 6.

My old clerk of the
Revolution -- Julia
Brown lost her little
boy Georgie -- the 12th
entries.summaryText: Julia Brown lost her little boy Georgie.

entries.fullText:
Eugene returned at
10 P.M -- had not
been to Easton -- till
Sunday A.M -- & then got
word of the Briggs waiting
him --had staid at the
Widow Joseph Moshers
all the time
entries.summaryText: Eugene returned and stayed at Widow Joseph Mosher's all the time.

entries.fullText:
Eugene took 11 P.M.
N.Y. Central for New
York -- Aaron & he went
to Col. Hay's Temp. Tent --
Meeting -- & A. left him at
Depot at 10 P.M -- My
last words to him were to remember
& report himself
this time -
entries.summaryText: Eugene went to Col. Hay's Temp. Tent Meeting and left for New York with Aaron.

entries.fullText: Miss Cleveland came to help make into a patch-book - all of my 25 years clipping from newspaper reports &c -
entries.summaryText: Miss Cleveland came to help make a patch-book of newspaper clippings.

entries.fullText: Louise returned home from niece Maggies had been there over two weeks
entries.summaryText: Louise returned home from visiting Maggie.

entries.fullText: good letters from Frank and Wendell
entries.summaryText: Received good letters from Frank and Wendell.

entries.fullText: AUGUST, FEBRUARY 23. 1878.
AUGUST, SUNDAY 25, 1878

MONDAY 26
Sister May & Miss
Collins returned from
their Ocean Grove trip
entries.summaryText: Sister May and Miss Collins returned from their Ocean Grove trip on Monday 26.

entries.fullText: AUGUST, THURSDAY 27. 1878.
WEDNESDAY 28.
AUGUST, THURSDAY 29, 1878.
FRIDAY 30.

Telegram from brother
D.R.. that St John was
nominated for Gov. of
Kansas -
entries.summaryText: Susan received a telegram from her brother D.R. stating that St John was nominated for Governor of Kansas.

entries.fullText:
Took 7.20 A. M. train
for Fayetteville - found the Gages
at dinner -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony took a train to Fayetteville and had dinner with the Gages.

entries.fullText:
Returned from
Mrs Gages on 5 P.M. train
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony returned from Mrs Gages on a 5 P.M. train.

entries.fullText:
SEPTEMBER, SUNDAY 8. 1878
MONDAY 9.
entries.summaryText: Journal entry from September 8, 1878.

entries.fullText:
SEPTEMBER, TUESDAY 10. 1878
Four weeks to day
since Eugene left
and not a line from
him. it is very strange
WEDNESDAY 11.
entries.summaryText: Journal entry from September 10, 1878 about Eugene not contacting Susan B. Anthony since leaving four weeks prior.

entries.fullText: Learned that Mrs Briggs had not heard from Eugene -
entries.summaryText: Mrs Briggs had not heard from Eugene.

entries.fullText: Wrote E. S. Caldwell to know if Eugene had been there - it is surely very strange -
entries.summaryText: Wrote E. S. Caldwell to know if Eugene had been there.

entries.fullText:
Received letters
from Elisha Caldwell
-H. Lapham, L. Sequier
& Harvey Mosher -
that Eugene had not
been seen- So we
made up our minds
to advertise in New York
papers at once-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony received letters from Elisha Caldwell, H. Lapham, L. Sequier, and Harvey Mosher, stating that Eugene had not been seen. They decided to advertise in New York papers.

entries.fullText:
This is dear sister
Hannah's birth day -
57 years- she would have
been - it is too cruel that
we must lose her- such a
joy & stay to her children & to
us -- While Eugene is left - a
weight for all to carry - he
reported to Louise to day - after
a silence of five weeks -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her sister Hannah's birthday and how difficult it is to lose her. She also mentions Eugene and his recent communication with Louise.

entries.fullText:
14 years ago to day- niece
Ann Eliza McLean was buried
and 40 years ago to day
sister Guelma was
married -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony reflects on the anniversaries of her niece Ann Eliza McLean's burial and her sister Guelma's marriage.

entries.fullText:
(Mary Dobbins married
John Joseph Birmingham this
at 8 1/2 O clock- to settle in
Buffalo - marriage in Cathedral)
Expected sister
Annie & Susie B. this
P.M. - - but didn't come
Mother a little improved
- but eats nothing -
entries.summaryText: Mary Dobbins married John Joseph Birmingham and Susan expected her sisters but they didn't come. Mother is a little improved but not eating.

entries.fullText:
Mary Dobbins married
this Thursday A.M. -
At noon mother began
to feel like eating - and
grew more & more like
herself -
entries.summaryText: Mary Dobbins married and mother began to feel like eating and grew more like herself.

entries.fullText:
Mother still brighter
- but cant move
her body - only her feet
& legs & arms --
It seems a great
relief to have the
change fom the
reign of May Dobbins
over the kitchen -
entries.summaryText: Mother is still brighter but can't move her body, only her feet, legs, and arms. It's a relief to have a change from the reign of May Dobbins over the kitchen.

entries.fullText:
My friend Eliz. Cady Stanton's
oldest daughter- Margaret Livingston
Stanton was married at 12 O clock
to day to Frank Eugene Lawrence
of Omaha Nebraska - & sent me
their card- 'Mr & Mrs Frank Eugene
Lawrence - If Mrs S. daughter is
this happy to be dropped out of sight
name & all - what hope of the
daughters generally -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony's friend Eliz. Cady Stanton's daughter, Margaret Livingston Stanton, got married to Frank Eugene Lawrence of Omaha, Nebraska.

entries.fullText: Tuesday, 15.

The Editor. Lewis E. Chapin
-- guest of Mrs. Charlotte A. Cleveland --
two daughters & lovely home --
Left Rochester at 6:30 -- on State
Line -- reached Perry at 11 A.M.,
Mrs C. drove me round to Silver
Lake camp meeting grounds &
The Pioneers Cabin -- had a
fine audience Universalist [?]
-- gave Bread & Ballot --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Perry, Wyoming Co. N.Y. and gives a speech on women's suffrage at Silver Lake camp meeting grounds.

entries.fullText:
Left Perry at 7 A.M. -- via
Salamanca, Meadville &
stopped at Russel Ohio over
night -- arriving 8 O clock

J.E. Graham -
Spoke in Presbyterian Church -
the Pres. Minister introducing me
& approving my lecture name McKellup
- after lecture attended the Agnes
[?alla?c]-Villa theater - (The Celebrated case) & (Loose Cheese?) - The
latter a most pitiable spectacle
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke at the Presbyterian Church in Richville, Ohio, and attended a theater performance afterwards.

entries.fullText:
C.L. Kurtz -
guest of Mrs. A. S. Currier
Brown - daughter Mary
Lyle Brown - small
audience - Presbyterian
Synod in session - & did
not adjourn - not doing as they
would [?] do me
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was a guest of Mrs. A. S. Currier Brown in Athens, Ohio, and attended a Presbyterian Synod.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Brown & daughter
went with us to the
Insane Asylum - Dr
Clark - the new Superintendent
- Minister preached on 'Christ
died for us' - 4 divisions - [?]
four words - I followed & said
I loved to think of how Christ
lived for us - the Priest
looked [?] enough - but
the Supt said just the
right word --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visited the Insane Asylum with Mrs. Brown and attended a sermon on 'Christ died for us'.

entries.fullText:
Ironton - Ohio Baptist Church
Mr C. M. McConaughy
- Dr. Moxley - one of Com-
guest of Mrs - Willard
Husband the National Banker
3 daughters - eldest a
widow with 3 children Mrs Scott.
youngest Mrs Moulton - 2nd one
an invalid - rain poured —
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her visit to the Ironton - Ohio Baptist Church and the people she met there.

entries.fullText:
Left I at 8 A.M.
arrived Portsmouth noon -
had to spend night - & later
Thursday A.M. train at 7.20 -
sent Mary money borrowed - also
Mrs Gage - & Mrs Sargent -
balance of July meetings -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her travel to Portsmouth and sending money to Mary, Mrs Gage, and Mrs Sargent.

entries.fullText:
Parkersburg - West Va -
W. R. Alexander M.D.
Stopped at Hills Hotel
spoke in M.E. Church -
Rev. Mr Chambers introduced
me - W.H. Warner -
Got first letter
from home here - dear
mother improving - & very
happy in spirit -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her visit to Parkersburg - West Va, speaking at the M.E. Church, and receiving a letter from home about her mother's improving health.

entries.fullText:
Left P. at 10.30 -
had 2 hours at Athens -
called at the Brown's &
lunched - another hour
Lancaster - & reached Zanesville
at 7 P.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her travel from Parkersburg to Zanesville, stopping at Athens and Lancaster along the way.

entries.fullText:
P. T. Copeland
Wm. Mangold -
stopped Clarendon Hotel -
Harris Proprietor -
worked hard all day on new
lecture - Capital & Labor - &
gave it - was advertised Bread & Bal
but gave that under title of 16th Am't
two years ago when here -
Small Audience _
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gave a lecture on Capital & Labor at Zanesville Ohio to a small audience.

entries.fullText:
Gave Temperance lecture
at 3 P.M. Mrs Agnes M.
Johnson M.D. introduced me - she
is Pres. city Tem. League -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gave a Temperance lecture at Zanesville - O. introduced by Mrs Agnes M. Johnson M.D.

entries.fullText:
Students {S. E. Bartmers
{W.H. miller
President H. A. Thompson -
Otterbein University _
Fine Audience - in
the Chapel - guest of Pres.
& Mrs Thompson - Mrs
Stanton & Mr Phillips there
last year -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gave a lecture at Otterbein University to a fine audience in the Chapel and was a guest of President H. A. Thompson and Mrs Thompson. Mrs Stanton & Mr Phillips were there last year.

entries.fullText:
H. Baxter
Sarah F. Hagar -
rainy night - small
audience -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gave a lecture at Ashley O. to a small audience on a rainy night.

entries.fullText:
W. G. Beebe
Dr. Vorhies & Mrs Emily
Vorhies - their daughter
is wife of Mr Bieber
small audience - immensely
large hall
entries.summaryText: Attended a small event in Mount Gilead with W. G. Beebe, Dr. Vorhies, Mrs Emily Vorhies, and Mr Bieber.

entries.fullText:
Mrs R. J. House - of Cameron
MO - she is granddaughter of a
sister of Aunt Ruth Vails, Hannah
Rogers [H] & daughter of Lydia R
Kerse - who was brought up by
Aunt Sarah Otis of Harris Ohio.
Mrs. D. V. Wherry & Mrs S. A. Moad
the leading Temp. woman here
entries.summaryText: Met with Mrs R. J. House and other women in Cardington, O. and discussed family connections and the temperance movement.

entries.fullText:
Left Mrs Mary Jane
House's at noon- met
Geo. J. Wood - Ashley O
Frank E. Stanley - Cardington
and A. H . Millar all new
light - Orthodox Friends - Stanley
a preacher - on way to Greenwich
O. for Quarterly meeting
at Crestline wrote home & sent
$180 to D.R. - which gives us a net of
$200 for half month's work
entries.summaryText: Traveled to various locations including Ashley O, Cardington, Greenwich O, Crestline, and Wooster -O. and met with various individuals including Geo. J. Wood, Frank E. Stanley, and A. H . Millar. Sent money home and discussed finances.

entries.fullText:
[E. B. Eshelman & Co.]
P. C. Given - T. E. Peckingburgh - Con.
arrived 9:15 last night, letters from
sister Mary, Wendell & Frank
all good words - but was
so full of home & loved
ones-hard time to get to sleep
--prof. O. A. Stoddard
presented me to audience
entries.summaryText: Met with E. B. Eshelman & Co., P. C. Given, and T. E. Peckingburgh in Wooster -O. and received letters from family members. Presented to an audience by prof. O. A. Stoddard.

entries.fullText:
day pleasant - went out to
dinner at W. D. Barretts -
has six daughters & 4 sons - & most
of them & wives called - Dr. J. E.
Mila a teacher - Nellie Spectman
a widow & fathers book keeper
J. R. Woodworth, a son in law
member of Kansas 15th Reg. & was
with brothers D. R. & J. M. in war
entries.summaryText: Went out to dinner at W. D. Barretts with several people including Dr. J. E. Mila and J. R. Woodworth.

entries.fullText:
Doylestown - O, - Geo. W Evarts
S. H. Miller - Rich man
of the village - Reaping [?]
but Mr Chaplin of Buffalo N.Y.
Eugene - Day magnificent
large audience - spoke on
Temperance
entries.summaryText: Spoke on Temperance to a large audience in Doylestown.

entries.fullText:
Lovely day - a good honest [?]
young man killed this A.M.
a Brakesman - sad sad
Letter from Sister Annie - she
is back home to our Rochester home,
& Mrs. Muggen - her land lady
of R. R. Eating House an earnest
woman.
entries.summaryText: Received a letter from Sister Annie and heard about a young man who was killed in West Salem.

entries.fullText:
Stopped McNulty Hotel - Mrs.
Emma R. Coe stopped with her
20 years ago - when lecturing in
Mrs. McM was the widow
- then & had lost all of
her dead husband going bail for 3,000
before he died
entries.summaryText: Stayed at McNulty Hotel and saw Mrs. Emma R. Coe who she had met 20 years ago.

entries.fullText:
F. R. Loomis
Ms. Frank M. Paul- formerly Amanda
M. Cole -Washington Co. N.Y. daughter of
Curtis Cole - now of [Lexington KY]
Knoxville - Tennessee called on
me here - Caroline Cole & Anson
Collins- live five miles out of City
and called
Jeremiah N. Robinson - true
leading temperance man
Mrs. M. A. Bronson-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives visitors from various places and meets with a leading temperance man.

entries.fullText:
Ashtabula- Ohio
Mrs P. H Watson -
[Jeremiah N. Robinson - the
[?]] Mr Watson was private Sec'y
of Secretary Stanton - Elegant
home & a cordial welcome
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Ashtabula and Canal Fulton and is welcomed by Mrs. P. H. Watson and Mr. Watson, who was a private secretary of Secretary Stanton.

entries.fullText:
Port Clinton, Ohio
Geo. R. Clark
Arrived at 4.20 P.M.
was greet of Mrs. Mary Motley -
was teacher of Public School - the
German element wanted a man -
so she - 4 years ago started high school
in her own house & has all of [?]
advanced pupils - some 30 or 40 every
semester
Felt miserably for
over eating at Mrs. Watsons
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives in Port Clinton and meets with Mrs. Mary Motley, who started a high school in her own house. She also feels unwell after overeating at Mrs. Watson's.

entries.fullText:
Took 4. P.M. train
for Toledo - Carrie
Mott - Anna Caroline - daughter
of Richard Mott - met me
at Depot - & a warm welcome
I had from Richard - Mrs
Williams not home yet - her
daughter Lottie at Mr. Motts
ready to meet me
Felt incredibly good for
nothing to day
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Toledo and is welcomed by Richard, Carrie Mott, and Anna Caroline. She spends the day with them and feels good for doing nothing.

entries.fullText:
Left Toledo at 10:45. Had small
audience--& made poor speech
--still Mr. Davis said many expressed
their great pleasure--
got letter [?] from home--
mother going--but dear
sister Mary dreadfully over
taxed--nurse girl doesn't
seem to lessen her work so much
as we expected--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Toledo and gave a poor speech in front of a small audience. She received a letter from home and learned that her mother was going, but her sister Mary was overtaxed.

entries.fullText:
Hamilton--Ohio--
B.R. Brant--
Lou J. Beauchamp, a
reformed drunkard--an editor
& Temperance Lecturer now--
met me at Depot--Stopped
at Mrs Straubs Temperance Hotel
--daughter Mrs Weiler & Miss Straub
Reader & [?]--Had a [fured?] 50cts
audience--& made one of my best speeches
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony met with B.R. Brant and Lou J. Beauchamp, a reformed drunkard and editor, in Hamilton, Ohio. She stayed at Mrs. Straub's Temperance Hotel and gave one of her best speeches to an audience that paid 50 cents.

entries.fullText:
Aurora--Ind--
Will A. Greer
Left H. at 5.30--& arrived
at A. at 8.45--lovely day--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony traveled from Hamilton to Aurora, Indiana to meet with Will A. Greer on a lovely day.

entries.fullText:
London--O.
Puyton H. Acton
Letter from brother D.R.
in answer to mine about Frank
--thinks I know nothing of the case--
& he knows all & has done best possible
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony received a letter from her brother D.R. regarding Frank and was told that she knows nothing of the case and that he has done the best possible.

entries.fullText:
Waynesville --O--
Sweet & Cadwallader
Stopped [ebixile?] friend's
Janneys daughter
Nannie Janney
Lovely day
Letter from Mrs. Spencer
Splendid letter from Mrs
Stanton - that did my soul
good - her Hattie is a joy to her -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives letters from Mrs. Spencer and Mrs. Stanton, and visits Janneys in Waynesville.

entries.fullText:
Lebanon - O -
O.P. Kinsey
Found letter from Wendell - he is at
Vincennes Ind--trying Accident Insurance
with Arthur - also a word on wrapper
saying direct your next to Fort Scott-
So I fear he has left -P.O.
Mr Janney drove me
over to L.-- rainy day
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a letter from Wendell and visits Lebanon with Mr. Janney.

entries.fullText:
At Lebanon
Mrs Hartough wanted to
vote for 10 years--
Had fine audience
for Temperance this
evening--& a solid vote
standing for woman
suffrage--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks about temperance and woman suffrage to a receptive audience in Lebanon.

entries.fullText:
Germantown, O.
F.D. Harkrider
Drove across the county
16 miles--lovely drive--
stopped at Richard Schaeffers
daughter,--fine musician & composer
sent piece to each of my three nieces
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Germantown and stops at Richard Schaeffers' daughter's house.

entries.fullText: Jno. M Brodrick arrived 4 P.M. Spoke in new & beautiful Opera house -But had to have front curtain drawn to shut off the cavernous depths of cold air that came beating down on my poor head & back -- , Mr. Ryan introduced me- fine audience. Have to 2 oclock A.M. train for Dunkirk.
entries.summaryText: Spoke in new & beautiful Opera house in Marysville, O. with Jno. M Brodrick and Mr. Ryan introduced me.

entries.fullText: S.B. Davis Ed. The Paper & very enthusiastic Hard time at Hotel - so noisy I couldn't sleep in P. M - after an all night awake.
entries.summaryText: Stayed in Dunkirk - O. with S.B. Davis who was very enthusiastic but had a hard time sleeping at the noisy hotel.

entries.fullText: Stopped at J.B. Higbee's Excellent People - - perfectly in love with Ms Livermore - - She has spoken here 2 times - Mrs Stanton once -
entries.summaryText: Stopped at J.B. Higbee's in Bellevue - O. and met excellent people who were in love with Ms Livermore and Mrs Stanton who have both spoken there before.

entries.fullText: Stopped at R. J. Ritherts - E. T. Hartley - Principal of Public School boarded there. also several Lady teachers - this is Mr Charles Foster. M.C. from This District - he gone to W, his Father & Wife & daughter present Mine was the 1st lecture by a woman & on this question here
entries.summaryText: Stopped at R. J. Ritherts in Fostoria - O. and met Eshelman & Hale, E. T. Hartley, Mr Charles Foster, and several Lady teachers. Mr Charles Foster's Father & Wife & daughter were present. Mine was the 1st lecture by a woman & on this question here.

entries.fullText:
Stopped at Hopkins Hotel -
Col. Shannon very friendly
& also the Probate Judge
fine audience
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stopped at Hopkins Hotel in Bowling Green, Ohio. She met with Col. Shannon and the Probate Judge who were both friendly. She also had a fine audience.

entries.fullText:
spoke on temperance at
Court House at
2 P.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke on temperance at the Court House in Bowling Green, Ohio at 2 P.M.

entries.fullText:
Just two young fellows
got up the lecture -
Splendid audience
The best paying I've
seen this year - my
half $57.50
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to Lima, Ohio and attended a lecture given by two young fellows. She had a splendid audience and it was the best paying she had seen that year, earning her half $57.50.

entries.fullText:
Stopped at Hotel -
Rufus Wilson lives
Looks as if he patronized
the whiskey too much
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stopped at a hotel in Union City, Indiana. She met with B. P. Gray and saw Rufus Wilson who appeared to patronize whiskey too much.

entries.fullText:
M.A. Schrock
Terrible snow storm
very small audience

Took dinner at Presbyterian Hall
at Decatur--Day bright but
very sloppy--Had very
fine audience at La Grange
--Have to get up at
5 A.M. to go to Muncie
